across.text: Open wide his cell, but not completely
across.explanation: DEHISCE(i.e. “open wide”). “But not completely” indicates the solution is hidden in the clue, like so: WI(DE HIS CE)LL. Cool word, but a brute force of Chambers was needed to get it.

across.text: Mechanic’s grand when in better shape
across.explanation: GAS FITTER(i.e. “mechanic”). Solution is G (a recognised abbreviation of “grand”) followed by AS (i.e. “when”) and FITTER (i.e. “in better shape”).

across.text: Sunlight makes ozone gas, initially producing this?
across.explanation: SMOG. “Initially” indicates the solution is derived by taking the first letters ofSUNLIGHTMAKESOZONEGAS. Not sure of the science behind this one, but then I’m no scientist.

across.text: Until David is prepared to tour India, he’s not a team player
across.explanation: INDIVIDUALIST(i.e. “he’s not a team player”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “prepared”) of UNTIL DAVID IS which is wrapped around or “touring” I (“India” in the phonetic alphabet). A clue that scans rather well.

across.text: Greeks exploited this devious foresight
across.explanation: GIFT HORSE(i.e. “Greeks exploited this”, referring to the Trojan Horse used by the Greeks to infiltrate the city of Troy). “Devious” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of FORESIGHT.

across.text: County with lots of money transferred electronically?
across.explanation: DOWNLOADED(i.e. “transferred electronically”). Solution is DOWN (i.e. “[Irish] County”) followed by LOADED (i.e. “with loads of money”).

across.text: Remove police officers from allotment again as punishment
across.explanation: RETRIBUTION(i.e. “punishment”).Not sure about this one, so watch out. I guess the solution is derived by “removing” some letters from RE(AT)TRIBUTION (i.e. “allotment again”), but I can’t see how AT gets you “police officers”.[EDIT – Mick comes to the rescue in the comments, highlighting that the word ought to have been REDISTRIBUTION. If one removes DIS (being Detective Inspectors, i.e. “police officers”), you then get RETRIBUTION. Thanks, Mick! – LP]

across.text: Prominent feature of unfinished material
across.explanation: CHINO(i.e. “material”). Solution is CHIN (i.e. “prominent feature”) followed by O (i.e. “of unfinished”, i.e. the word “of” with the last letter removed).

across.text: As many plays are to Mike touring revolutionary Havana
across.explanation: TRAGICOMIC(i.e. “as many plays are”). Solution is TO and MIC (i.e. “Mike”, both recognised words for a microphone) wrapped around or “touring” CIGAR (i.e. “Havana”) which is reversed (indicated by “revolutionary”), like so: T(RAGIC)O-MIC.

across.text: Cleverly obtain women’s view
across.explanation: WANGLE(i.e. “cleverly obtain”). Solution is W (a recognised abbreviation of “women”) and ANGLE (i.e. “view”).

across.text: Fine old important ass with no name
across.explanation: OKEY-DOKEY(i.e. “fine”, as in a word of assent). Solution is O (a recognised abbreviation of “old”) followed by KEY (i.e. “important”) and DONKEY (i.e. “ass”) with the N removed (indicated by “no name” – N being a recognised abbreviation of “name”), like so: O-KEY-DOKEY.

across.text: Start university owing money?
across.explanation: DEBUT(i.e. “start”). Solution is U (a recognised abbreviation of “university”) placed in DEBT. The “owing money” bit plays on how the U is placed “in DEBT” to derive the solution. You get the idea.

across.text: A copper breaking up rave’s beaming
across.explanation: RADIANT(i.e. “beaming”). Solution is A DI (i.e. “a copper”, specifically a Detective Inspector) placed in or “breaking up” RANT (i.e. “rave”), like so: R(A-DI)ANT.

across.text: Top sailor and German worker make more than enough
across.explanation: SUPERABUNDANT(i.e. “more than enough”). Solution is SUPER (i.e. “top”) followed by AB (i.e. “sailor”, specifically one of the Able Bodied variety) then UND (i.e. “and German”, i.e. the German for “and”) and ANT (i.e. “worker”).

across.text: Drop two drinks containing last of gin
across.explanation: DOWNSWING(i.e. “drop”). Solution is DOWN and SWIG (i.e. “two drinks”) wrapped around or “containing” N (i.e. “last of gin”, i.e. the last letter of “gin”), like so: DOWN-SWI(N)G.

across.text: American sent back a strong beer brought in for each fan
across.explanation: SUPPORTER(i.e. “fan”).Solution can be US (i.e. “American”) reversed (indicated by “sent back”) and PORTER (i.e. “a strong beer”) once P (i.e. “for each”, or per – I’m guessing the setter has “per annum” in mind here, often shortened to “pa”, but in isolation this is not an abbreviation of “per” that is recognised by my Chambers) is “brought in” between them, like so: SU-(P)-PORTER. Alternatively, if you pretend for a moment that the setter’s screwed up, that PORT is a strong beer and not fortified wine, then you could place it in PER (being “for each”), like so: SU-P(PORT)ER. Either way, this ain’t great. Next!!!

across.text: Called bully regularly in Euston, say, for using throttle
across.explanation: STRANGULATION(i.e. “using throttle”). Solution is RANG (i.e. “called [on the telephone]”) and UL (i.e. “bully regularly”, i.e. every other letter ofBULLY) placed “in” STATION (i.e. “Euston, say”), like so: ST(RANG-UL)ATION.

across.text: You brought in coffee and baby’s clothing
across.explanation: LAYETTE(i.e. “baby’s clothing”). Solution is YE (i.e. ye olde “you”) placed “in” LATTE (i.e. “coffee”), like so: LA(YE)TTE. Another go-to solution for setters it seems, having recently appearedhereandhere.

across.text: Cunning servicemen open case of claret
across.explanation: CRAFT(i.e. “cunning”). Solution is RAF (i.e. “servicemen”, specifically the Royal Air Force) placed in or “opening” CT (i.e. “case of claret”, i.e. the first and last letters of “claret”), like so: C(RAF)T.

across.text: Check what golfer does on tee to try out buggy?
across.explanation: TEST DRIVE. Solution is TEST (i.e. “[to] check”) followed by DRIVE (i.e. “what golfer does on tee”). Test drives are taken in motor vehicles by prospective owners in order to “try them out”. A golf “buggy” might be one such vehicle, at a stretch. You get the idea.

across.text: Charge the German for trough
across.explanation: FEEDER(i.e. “trough”). Solution is FEE (i.e. “charge”) followed by DER (i.e. “the German”, i.e. the German for “the”).

across.text: Angle to pay for drink, including duck
across.explanation: STANDPOINT(i.e. “angle”). Solution is STAND PINT (i.e. “to pay for drink”) wrapped around or “including” O (i.e. “duck”, being a zero score in cricket), like so: STAND-P(O)INT.

across.text: Republican university withdraws race
across.explanation: RELAY(i.e. “race”). Solution is R (a recognised abbreviation of “Republican”) followed by YALE (i.e. “[American] university”) which is reversed (indicated by “withdraws”), like so: R-ELAY.

across.text: Study society involved in racket with your authority
across.explanation: CONNOISSEUR(i.e. “authority”).Another one I’m not 100% on, so watch out. Solution is CON (an archaic word for “study” often used by setters) followed by S (a recognised abbreviation of “society”) once it has been placed or “involved” in NOISE (i.e. “racket”). I’m guessing the setter then means UR to be “your”, to then make CON-NOIS(S)E-UR, but this usage isn’t supported by any of my assorted reference books. If the intention was a contraction of “you are”, then 1) “you’re” is not the same as “your”, and 2) some kind of homophone indicator should have been used. So are we allowing textspeak now, setters, or am I missing something? Hmm. Given my recent form, the latter is a possibility…[EDIT – After sneaking a look in a few other dictionaries, I see the latest Oxford lists UR as an abbreviation of “your”. Shame, Oxford! Shame!(Rings bell.)– LP]

across.text: Goods in a recession ignoring City’s hostility
across.explanation: AGGRESSION(i.e. “hostility”). Solution is GG (i.e. “goods” – G is a recognised abbreviation of “good”, so GG would be the plural “goods”) placed “in” A RECESSION once the letters EC have been removed (indicated by “ignoring City” – EC is the post code area of the City of London), like so: A(GG)RESSION.

across.text: Gentleman calling for taxi briskly, good to go
across.explanation: CABALLERO(i.e. a Spanish “gentleman”). Solution is CAB (i.e. “taxi”) followed by ALLEGRO (i.e. “fast” in musical lingo) once the G (a recognised abbreviation of “good”) has been removed, like so: CAB-ALLERO.

across.text: Run new article about outcome of WWIII?
across.explanation: NUCLEAR WINTER(i.e. “outcome of WWIII”). “About” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of RUN NEW ARTICLE.

across.text: First female premier’s right wing, still
across.explanation: EVER(i.e. “still”). Solution is EVE (i.e. “[Biblical] first female”) followed by R (i.e. “premier’s right wing”, i.e. the last letter of “premier”).

across.text: Baked bits and pieces bits Kitty dumps across river
across.explanation: POTSHERDS, which, in archaeological terms, are fragments of pottery (i.e. “baked bits and pieces”). Solution is POT (i.e. “kitty” as in a pot of money – ignore the misleading capitalisation) followed by SHEDS (i.e. “dumps”) once it has been wrapped around or placed “across” R (a recognised abbreviation of “river”), like so: POT-SHE(R)DS. A new word on me, but not one I can see using in conversation anytime ever.Also, the second mention of “bit” seems redundant, unless it’s supposed to qualify “kitty” – bits being another word for coins. Given that the second “bit” doesn’t scan at all well within the clue, I’m guessing this is an editor fail.

across.text: Battle colour
across.explanation: MAGENTA. Solution satisfies “battle” – referring to the Battle of Magenta fought during the Second Italian War of Independence in 1859 (so says Wikipedia, anyway) – and “colour”.

down.text: Stage cow, perhaps, with no tail
down.explanation: DAIS(i.e. “stage”).Another where the setter shakes me off, so be aware. My best guess is that the solution is derived from DAISY with the last letter removed (indicated by “with no tail”), but I’m not getting how this is a “cow, perhaps”. There’s probably some enormous neon-lit cultural reference I’m missing somewhere.

down.text: Extremely happy vet maybe with leather needing horse compound
down.explanation: HYDROXIDE(i.e. “compound” of hydrogen and oxygen). Solution is HY (i.e. “extremely happy”, i.e. the first and last letters of “happy”) followed by DR (a recognised abbreviation of doctor, i.e. “vet maybe”) and OX HIDE (i.e. “leather”) with the H removed (indicated by “needing horse” – H being a recognised abbreviation of heroin, also known as “horse”), like so: HY-DR-OX-IDE.

down.text: Son still muses on mundane old edifices, including a lighthouse
down.explanation: SEVEN WONDERS OF THE WORLD(i.e. “old edifices, including a lighthouse” – the latter referring to the Lighthouse of Alexandria). Solution is S (a recognised abbreviation of “son”) followed by EVEN (i.e. “still” – 54a has EVER being “still”, 3d has EVEN being “still” – both work), then WONDERS (i.e. “muses on”) and OF THE WORLD (i.e. “mundane”).

down.text: Final violent demonstration missing quota
down.explanation: ENDMOST(i.e. “final”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “violent”) ofDEMONSTRATION once the RATION has been removed (indicated by “missing quota”).

down.text: King George with cleric going round Yankee landmark
down.explanation: GRAND CANYON(i.e. “landmark”). Solution is GR (i.e. “King George” or Georgius Rex in Latin) followed by AND (i.e. “with”) and CANON (i.e. “cleric”) once it has been placed “around” Y (“Yankee” in the phonetic alphabet), like so: GR-AND-CAN(Y)ON.

down.text: Cool GP, seen running round getting dehydrated fast?
down.explanation: SPIN-DRIED(i.e. “getting dehydrated fast”, or at least faster than being left out in the open). Solution is SPIED (i.e. “seen”) placed “round” IN (i.e. hip and happening and “cool”) and DR (a recognised abbreviation of “doctor”, i.e. “GP” or General Practitioner), like so: SP(IN-DR)IED.

down.text: Season without wife’s place in ground
down.explanation: INTER(i.e. “place in ground”). Solution is WINTER (i.e. “season”) with the W removed (indicated by “without wife” – W being a recognised abbreviation of “wife”).

down.text: Grasping digits the FT put about
down.explanation: TIGHTFISTED(i.e. “grasping”). “Put about” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of DIGITS THE FT.

down.text: Fliers on female, one supported by a hat-maker
down.explanation: RAFFIA(i.e. “hat-maker”. It is also used to make other things, like mats and baskets.) Solution is RAF (i.e. “fliers”) followed by F (a recognised abbreviation of “female”), then I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”) and A. The “supported by” bit relates to how these pieces are all stacked on top of the final A, this being a down clue.

down.text: Greeting old seafarers in China
down.explanation: MORNING(i.e. “greeting” – hoo boy, the swearing when this finally clicked!) Solution is O (a recognised abbreviation of “old”) and RN (i.e. “seafarers”, specifically the Royal Navy) placed “in” MING (i.e. “china” – ignore the misleading capitalisation), like so: M(O-RN)ING.

down.text: A degree in martial arts restricted building here
down.explanation: GREEN BELT. Solution satisfies “a degree in martial arts” and “restricted building here”.

down.text: Somehow understanding solids has special relish
down.explanation: THOUSAND ISLAND DRESSING(i.e. “relish”). Both “somehow” and “special” appear to be anagram indicators here, which seems a tad excessive. Unless thousand island dressing is indeed “special”. Never tried it. Solution is an anagram of UNDERSTANDING SOLIDS HAS. An easier get, having appeared ina previous grid.

down.text: Rich man’s wrinkles mentioned?
down.explanation: CROESUS(i.e. “rich man”). “Mentioned” indicates homophone. Solution is a homophone of CREASES (i.e. “wrinkles”). Another easier get, having appeared ina previous grid.

down.text: Troops maybe fly spacecraft
down.explanation: ORBITER(i.e. “spacecraft”). Solution is OR (i.e. “troops”, specifically the Other Ranks of the British Army) followed by BITER (i.e. “maybe fly”. Other biters are available.)

down.text: Mature people occasionally want to enter gangs
down.explanation: GROWN-UPS(i.e. “mature people”). Solution is WN (i.e. “occasionally want”, i.e. every other letter ofWANT) placed in or “entering” GROUPS (i.e. “gangs”), like so: GRO(WN)UPS.

down.text: Royal couple, taking in current blitz, left out US meddler
down.explanation: KIBITZER, which is a Yiddish word used in the “US” to describe someone who interferes or gives unwanted advice, i.e. “meddler”. No, me neither. Solution is K and ER (i.e. “royal couple”, being recognised abbreviations of “king” and “Elizabeth Regina” respectively) wrapped around or “taking in” I (a recognised abbreviation for an electrical “current”) and BLITZ once the L has been removed (indicated by “left out” – L being a recognised abbreviation of “left”), like so: K-(I-BITZ)-ER.

down.text: Defence one entered, jumping bail
down.explanation: ALIBI(i.e. “defence”). Solution is I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”) placed in or “entering” an anagram (indicated by “jumping”) of BAIL, like so: AL(I)BI.

down.text: Drug source, old man with paltry margins
down.explanation: POPPY(i.e. “drug source”). Solution is POP (i.e. “old man”, both informal descriptions of one’s father) followed by PY (i.e. “paltry margins”, i.e. the first and last letters of “paltry”).

down.text: Volunteers in sailor’s home don’t drink
down.explanation: ABSTAIN(i.e. “don’t drink”). Solution is TA (i.e. “volunteers”, specifically the Territorial Army) placed “in” between AB’S (i.e. “sailor’s” – as mentioned earlier, AB is an Able-Bodied seaman) and IN (i.e. “home”), like so: AB’S-(TA)-IN.

down.text: Armaments chap holding notes and ruler
down.explanation: GUNNERY(i.e. “armaments”). Solution is GUY (i.e. “chap”) wrapped around or “holding” NN (i.e. “notes” – N is a recognised abbreviation of “note”, so NN makes a pair of “notes”) and ER (i.e. “ruler”, specifically Elizabeth Regina), like so: GU(NN-ER)Y.

down.text: Hack to back her to make waves
down.explanation: ROCK THE BOAT(i.e. “make waves”). “Hack” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of TO BACK HER TO.

down.text: Vacuum old object found in northern loch
down.explanation: NOTHINGNESS(i.e. “vacuum”). Solution is O (a recognised abbreviation of “old”) and THING (i.e. “object”) placed or “found in” N (a recognised abbreviation of “northern”) and NESS (i.e. “loch”), like so: N-(O-THING)-NESS.

down.text: Everyone goes through this lithium and iron carrier
down.explanation: LIFE CYCLE(i.e. “everyone goes through this”). Solution is LI (chemical symbol of “lithium”) and FE (ditto “iron”) followed by CYCLE (i.e. “carrier”, referring to a bicycle).

down.text: Noisy performer hit reindeer
down.explanation: TAP-DANCER(i.e. “noisy performer”). Solution is TAP (i.e. “hit”) followed by DANCER (i.e. “[Santa Claus’s] reindeer”).

down.text: I will try Times nurse acquired under the counter?
down.explanation: ILL-GOTTEN(i.e. “acquired under the counter”). Solution is I’LL (a contraction of “I will”) followed by GO (i.e. “try”, as in have a go), then TT (i.e. “times” – ignore the misleading capitalisation. T is a recognised abbreviation of “time”, and as we’ve seen a number of times, this week’s setter likes to use plurals to indicate repeated letters, so “times” becomes TT) and EN (i.e. “nurse”, specifically an Enrolled Nurse), like so: I’LL-GO-TT-EN.

down.text: Maybe make peeress some genteel bonnets in retirement
down.explanation: ENNOBLE(i.e. “maybe make peeress”). “Some” indicates the solution is hidden in the clue, while “in retirement” indicates the solution has been reversed, like so: GENTE(EL BONNE)TS.

down.text: Formula of The Golden Mean? Recall first half only
down.explanation: THEOREM(i.e. “formula”). Solution is THE followed by OR (i.e. “golden” in heraldry) and ME (i.e. “mean … first half only”) which is reversed (indicated by “recall”), like so: THE-OR-EM.

down.text: A former PM’s getting up numb
down.explanation: ASLEEP(i.e. “numb”). Solution is A followed by Robert PEEL’S (i.e. “former PM’s” – PM being Prime Minister) which is reversed (indicated by “getting up” – this being a down clue), like so: A-S’LEEP.

down.text: Spread limb, ignoring breadth
down.explanation: RANCH(i.e. “spread”). Solution is BRANCH (i.e. “limb” of a tree) with the B removed (indicated by “ignoring breadth” – B being a recognised abbreviation of “breadth”).

down.text: Swimmer that completes two of the Balearics
down.explanation: ORCA, a.k.a. a killer whale (i.e. “swimmer”). “That completes two of the Balearics” refers to MajORCAand MallORCA. Another repeated solution,this time from last month.
